LM.title: LM : Left main coronary artery
LM.location: The left main coronary artery emerges from the aorta through the ostia of the left aortic cusp, within the sinus of Valsalva.It travels from the aorta, and passes between the pulmonary trunk and the left atrial appendage. Under the appendage, the artery divides (and is thus a very short vessel) into the anterior interventricular (left anterior descending artery) and the left circumflex artery
LM.function: supply the majority of oxygenated blood to ventricular myocardium, and additionally to the left atrium, left atrial appendage, pulmonary artery, and aortic root.
defects: Atherosclerosis is a condition that involves thickening of the arterial walls via cholesterol and fat deposits that build up along the endoluminal surface of the arteries. With severe disease, these plaques may become calcified, increase in size, and eventually cause significant stenosis
LM.subtitle: AP

LAD.title: LAD: Left Anterior Descending
LAD.location: The left anterior descending (LAD, interventricular) artery appears to be a direct continuation of the left coronary artery which descends into the anterior interventricular groove.
LAD.function: LAD artery supply most of the interventricular septum; the anterior, lateral, and apical wall of the left ventricle, most of the right and left bundle branches, and the anterior papillary muscle of the bicuspid valve (left ventricle)
defects: The LAD artery is the most commonly occluded of the coronary arteries. It provides the major blood supply to the interventricular septum, and thus bundle branches of the conducting system. Hence, blockage of this artery due to coronary artery disease can lead to impairment or death (infarction) of the conducting system. The result is a "block" of impulse conduction between the atria and the ventricles known as "right/left bundle branch block."
LAD.subtitle: RAO Cranial

LCx.title: LCx : Left circumflex arteries
LCx.location: The circumflex artery branches off of the left coronary artery .
LCx.function: supplies most of the left atrium: the posterior and lateral free walls of the left ventricle, and part of the anterior papillary muscle. In 40-50% of hearts the circumflex artery supplies the artery to the SA node
LCx.subtitle: LAO Caudal

Septal branch.title: Septal branch
Septal branch.location: These are right-sided branches (on axial CTCA) from the left anterior descending artery.
Septal branch.function: They provide the main blood supply to the anterior interventricular septum. A smaller posterior section is also supplied from the posterior descending artery instead (see coronary arterial dominance).
Septal branch.subtitle: LAO Cranial

Diagonal branch.title: Diagonal branch
Diagonal branch.location: There are termed "diagonal" due to them branching from their parent vessel at acute angles. They extend over the left ventricle in a diagonal fashion toward the acute margin and the cardiac apex. They often run parallel to one another and are variable in number (often 2 to 9).
Diagonal branch.function: supply blood flow to the anterior and anterolateral walls of the left ventricle. There are usually denoted as D1, D2, D3, etc.
Diagonal branch.subtitle: RAO Cranial

RCA.title: RCA : Right coronary arteries
RCA.location: The right coronary artery emerges from the aorta into the AV groove. It descends through the groove, then curves posteriorly, and makes a bend at the crux of the heart and continues downward in the posterior interventricular sulcus
RCA.function: supply blood to the myocardium (heart tissue) itself; that is, coronary capillaries deliver oxygenated blood (nutrients) to all of the heart's cells. Numerous clinically relevant arterial branches arise from the right coronary artery, including those that supply the conduction system.
defects: Right coronary artery branches supply the sinus and atrioventricular nodes; hence, blockage in these vessels can lead to conduction abnormalities
Atherosclerosis is a condition that involves thickening of the arterial walls via cholesterol and fat deposits that build up along the endoluminal surface of the arteries.
RCA.subtitle: LAO

RMA.title: RMA : Right marginal artery
RMA.aka: aka: acute marginal artery or right intermediate atrial branch
RMA.location: arises from the inferior border of the right coronary artery at the acute right margin of the heart, ascending over the anterolateral surface of the right atrium
RMA.function: supplies the surrounding right atrial tissues and, in 10-15% of cases, provides the main arterial supply to the sinus node.
RMA.subtitle: LAO Cranial

PDA.title: PDA : Posterior Descending Artery
PDA.location: an artery that extends along the inferior interventricular sulcus. The artery supplies the posterior third of the interventricular septum through posterior septal perforating arteries. *The inferior interventricular artery can anastomose with the anterior interventricular artery, a branch of the left anterior descending (LAD), over the apex of the heart. It can also anastomose with the LAD through each vessel's respective septal perforators
PDA.function: supplies the diaphragmatic portion of the left ventricle
PDA.subtitle: LAO Cranial

PL.title: PL : Posterior left ventricular artery
PL.aka: aka: posterolateral artery or branch (PLA or PLB)
PL.location: arises from the right coronary artery in the typically right-dominant circulation as a terminal branch along with the posterior descending artery
PL.function: terminal branch of the coronary arterial system supplying the inferior portion of the heart.
PL.subtitle: LAO Cranial
